questiontext.text:
Verify Stokes' theorem for the vector field \(\underline{F} = x^2 \underline{i} + {@aa@} x y \underline{j} + z\underline{k}\) and the triangle with vertices at \((0,0,0)\), \(({@bb@},0,0)\) and \(({@bb@},{@cc@},0)\).

  1. First find the normal vector \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S}\)

    1. \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \mathrm{d}y \, \mathrm{d}z \, \underline{i}\),

    2. \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y \, \underline{j}\),

    3. \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y \, \underline{k}\)

    \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. Then find the vector \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}\)

    1. \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = {@aa@}y\underline{k}\)

    2. \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = {@aa@}y\underline{i}\)

    3. \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = {@aa@}x\underline{j}\)

    4. \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = {@aa@}x^2\underline{k}\)

    5. \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = {@aa@}xy\underline{i}\)

    6. \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = {@aa@}x^2\underline{j}\)

    \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

  3. Now evaluate the double integral \(\int_{x=0}^{@bb@} \int_{y=0}^{\frac{{@cc@}}{{@bb@}}x} ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\)

    Integral \(=\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

  4. Finally find the integral \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) by splitting the curve into the 3 sides of the triangle:

    1. Contribution to \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the line from \((0,0,0)\) to \(({@bb@},0,0) = \) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:prt4]]

    2. Contribution to \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the line from \(({@bb@},0,0)\) to \(({@bb@},{@cc@},0) = \) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]] [[feedback:prt5]]

    3. Contribution to \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the line from \(({@bb@},{@cc@},0)\) to \((0,0,0) = \) [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]] [[feedback:prt6]]

  5. Hence find the total line integral \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\)

    \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \) [[input:ans7]] [[validation:ans7]] [[feedback:prt7]]

generalfeedback.text:
We are asked to verify Stokes' theorem for the vector field \(\underline{F} = x^2 \underline{i} + {@aa@} x y \underline{j} + z\underline{k}\) and the triangle with vertices at \((0,0,0)\), \(({@bb@},0,0)\) and \(({@bb@},{@cc@},0)\).

  1. We are asked to first find the normal vector \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S}\)

    Since our triangle lies in the \(xy\) plane and therefore has unit normal vector \(\underline{k}\), \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y \, \underline{k}\)\)

  2. We are then asked to find the vector \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}\)

    \(\begin{align} {\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} \underline{i} & \underline{j} & \underline{k}\\ \\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ x^2 & {@aa@}xy & z \end{array} \right| &= \underline{i} \left| \begin{array}{cc} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ {@aa@}xy & z \end{array}\right| - \underline{j} \left| \begin{array}{cc} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ x^2 & z \end{array}\right| + \underline{k} \left| \begin{array}{cc} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \\ x^2 & {@aa@}xy \end{array}\right| \\ &= \underline{i} \left(0-0\right) - \underline{j} \left(0-0\right) + \underline{k} \left({@aa@}y - 0\right) \\ &= {@aa@}y\underline{k} \end{align}\)

  3. We are now asked to evaluate the double integral \(\int_{x=0}^{@bb@} \int_{y=0}^{\frac{{@cc@}}{{@bb@}}x} ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\)

    \(\begin{align} I &= \int_{x=0}^{@bb@} \int_{y=0}^{\frac{{@cc@}}{{@bb@}}x} ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} \\ &= \int_{x=0}^{@bb@} \int_{y=0}^{\frac{{@cc@}}{{@bb@}}x} {@aa@}y\underline{k} \cdot \mathrm{d}y \, \mathrm{d}x \, \underline{k} \\ &= \int_{x=0}^{@bb@} \int_{y=0}^{\frac{{@cc@}}{{@bb@}}x} {@aa@}y \, \mathrm{d}y \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int_{x=0}^{@bb@} \left[{@coeff1*y^2@}\right]_{y=0}^{\frac{{@cc@}}{{@bb@}}x} \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int_{x=0}^{@bb@} {@coeff2@} x^2 \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[{@coeff3@}x^3\right]_{x=0}^{@bb@} \\ &= {@coeff3@}({@bb@})^3 \\ &= {@ta3@} \end{align}\)

  4. Finally we are asked to find the integral \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) by splitting the curve into the 3 sides of the triangle:

    1. Contribution to \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the line from \((0,0,0)\) to \(({@bb@},0,0)\)

      \(\begin{align} I_1 &= \int_C (x^2 \underline{i} + {@aa@} x y \underline{j} + z\underline{k}) \cdot (\mathrm{d}x \underline{i} + \mathrm{d}y \underline{j}) \\ &= \int_C (x^2 \mathrm{d}x + {@aa@}xy \mathrm{d}y)\end{align}\)

      Going along the line \(y=0 \implies \dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = 0 \implies \mathrm{d}y=0\), and we have \(x\) ranging from \(0\) to \({@bb@}\), so

      \(\begin{align} I_1 &= \int_{x=0}^{@bb@} x^2 \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[\dfrac{x^3}{3}\right]_0^{@bb@} \\ &= \displaystyle {@ta4@} \end{align}\)

    2. Contribution to \(\oint_C\underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the line from \(({@bb@},0,0)\) to \(({@bb@},{@cc@},0)\)

      We again have

      \(I_2 = \int_C (x^2 \mathrm{d}x + {@aa@}xy \mathrm{d}y)\)

      Going along the line \(x={@bb@} \implies \dfrac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}y} = 0 \implies \mathrm{d}x=0\), and we have \(y\) ranging from \(0\) to \({@cc@}\), so

      \(\begin{align} I_2 &= \int_{y=0}^{@cc@} {@aa@}xy \, \mathrm{d}y \\ &= \displaystyle \left[{@aa/2@} xy^2\right]_0^{@cc@} \quad \text{and} \, x={@bb@}, \, \text{so} \\ &= \displaystyle \left[{@aa*bb/2@} y^2\right]_0^{@cc@} \\ &= \displaystyle {@ta5@} \end{align}\)

    3. Contribution to \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the line from \(({@bb@},{@cc@},0)\) to \((0,0,0)\)

      We again have

      \(I_3 = \int_C (x^2 \mathrm{d}x + {@aa@}xy \mathrm{d}y)\)

      Going along the line \(\displaystyle y={@cc/bb@}x \implies \dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = {@cc/bb@} \implies \mathrm{d}y={@cc/bb@}\mathrm{d}x\), and we have \(x\) ranging from \({@bb@}\) to \(0\), so

      \(\begin{align} I_3 &= \int_{x={@bb@}}^{0} x^2 \, \mathrm{d}x + {@aa@}x \left({@cc/bb@}x\right)\left({@cc/bb@}\mathrm{d}x\right) \\ &= \displaystyle \int_{x={@bb@}}^{0} x^2 \, \mathrm{d}x + {@coeff4@}x^2 \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \displaystyle {@coeff5@} \int_{x={@bb@}}^{0} x^2 \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \displaystyle {@coeff5@} \left[\dfrac{1}{3}x^3\right]_{@bb@}^0 \\ &= \displaystyle \left({@coeff5@}\right) \times \left(-\dfrac{1}{3}({@bb@})^3\right) \\ &= \displaystyle {@ta6@} \end{align}\)

  5. We are asked to hence find the total line integral \(\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\)

    The total line integral is equal to the sum of each contribution over the 3 sides, so

    \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = {@ta4@} + {@ta5@} \, {@ta6@} = {@ta7@} \)

    Which, as Stokes' theorem tells us, is the same as our evaluated double integral \(\int_{x=0}^{@bb@} \int_{y=0}^{\frac{{@cc@}}{{@bb@}}x} ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) in part (c).

questionnote.text:
\(\underline{F} = x^2 \underline{i} + {@aa@} x y \underline{j} + z\underline{k}\), and vertices \((0,0,0)\), \(({@bb@},0,0)\) and \(({@bb@},{@cc@},0)\).

Stokes' Theorem gives {@ta3@}

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
